dt: {bc}of less size, quality, degree, or significance {bc}of lower status

shortdef: of less size, quality, degree, or significance : of lower status

dt.t: big business trampling on the {wi}little{/wi} fellow

dt: {bc}existing only in a small amount or to a slight degree
{bc}existing to an appreciable though not extensive degree or amount

dt.t: had a {wi}little{/wi} money in the bank
a few {wi}little{/wi} problems to be dealt with

pt: {sc}small{/sc} {sc}little{/sc} {sc}diminutive{/sc} {sc}minute{/sc} {sc}tiny{/sc} {sc}miniature{/sc} mean noticeably below average in size. {sc}small{/sc} and {sc}little{/sc} are often interchangeable, but {sc}small{/sc} applies more to relative size determined by capacity, value, number.
{sc}little{/sc} is more absolute in implication often carrying the idea of petiteness, pettiness, insignificance, or immaturity.

pt.t: a {it}minute{/it} amount of caffeine in the soda

pt: {sc}miniature{/sc} applies to an exactly proportioned reproduction on a very small scale.

et: Middle English {it}littel{/it}, from Old English {it}lȳtel{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}luzzil{/it} little
shortdef: small in size or extent : tiny

dt: {bc}constituting a more limited number or amount

dt.t: no {wi}less{/wi} a person than the president himself

dt: used to emphasize that something is regarded as impressive or surprising

dt.t: wants to be driven to the airport, in a limousine {it}no less{/it}

pt: The traditional view is that {it}less{/it} applies to matters of degree, value, or amount and modifies collective nouns, mass nouns, or nouns denoting an abstract whole while {it}fewer{/it} applies to matters of number and modifies plural nouns. {it}Less{/it} has been used to modify plural nouns since the days of King Alfred and the usage, though roundly decried, appears to be increasing. {it}Less{/it} is more likely than {it}fewer{/it} to modify plural nouns when distances, sums of money, and a few fixed phrases are involved
and as likely as {it}fewer{/it} to modify periods of time.

et: Middle English, partly from Old English {it}lǣs{/it}, adverb & noun; partly from {it}lǣssa{/it}, adjective; akin to Old Frisian {it}lēs{/it} less
shortdef: constituting a more limited number or amount
of lower rank, degree, or importance
of reduced size, extent, or degree

dt: {bc}a yellow-flowered Eurasian perennial herb ({it}Ranunculus ficaria{/it}) of the buttercup family naturalized in North America

shortdef: a yellow-flowered Eurasian perennial herb (Ranunculus ficaria) of the buttercup family naturalized in North America

dt: {bc}a pyralid moth ({it}Elasmopalpus lignosellus{/it}) having slender greenish larvae that burrow in the stalk especially of corn near ground level

shortdef: a pyralid moth (Elasmopalpus lignosellus) having slender greenish larvae that burrow in the stalk especially of corn near ground level

dt: {bc}a clearwing moth ({it}Synanthedon pictipes{/it}) whose larva bores into the wood of stone-fruit trees and especially the peach

shortdef: a clearwing moth (Synanthedon pictipes) whose larva bores into the wood of stone-fruit trees and especially the peach

ins.il: plural in form but singular or plural in construction

dt: {bc}a common American marsh and shore bird ({it}Tringa flavipes{/it}) that closely resembles the greater yellowlegs in color and markings but is smaller with a shorter more slender bill

shortdef: a common American marsh and shore bird (Tringa flavipes) that closely resembles the greater yellowlegs in color and markings but is smaller with a shorter more slender bill
